mutationType.name: RootMutationType
mutationType.description:
This is the root of all GraphQL mutations. Unlike queries, mutations
represent actions that have a side effects, like `create` or `update`.

fields.name: taggingAddTagsToEntity
fields.description:
Adds the provided tags to your specified entity, without deleting existing ones.
 The maximum number of tag-values per entity is 100; if the sum of existing and new tag-values if over the limit this mutation will fail.

 For details and mutation examples, visit [our docs](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/nerdgraph/examples/nerdgraph-tagging-api-tutorial).

args.name: guid
args.description: The guid of the new entity.

args.name: tags
args.description: An array of key-values pairs to represent a tag. For example:  Team:TeamName.

fields.name: chaosStart
fields.description:
Begin a chaos test with the provided configuration.

When this mutation is run by a user, it will affect all queries made by that user
for 1 hour, or until the `chaosEnd` mutation is sent. Chaos testing is only available in `staging`.

For more information visit the [Chaos Testing docs](https://pages.datanerd.us/unified-api/nerd-graph-docs/operations/chaos_testing.html)

fields.name: nrdbQuery

A relevant `WHERE` clause will be added to your query to scope data to the entity in question.

See the [NRQL Docs](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/insights/nrql-new-relic-query-language/nrql-resources/nrql-syntax-components-functions) for more information about generating a query string.


---
**NR Internal** | visibility(customer)

args.description: The [NRQL](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/insights/nrql-new-relic-query-language/nrql-resources/nrql-syntax-components-functions) query string.

args.name: timeout
args.description: The timeout we will apply to the NRQL Query. The value will be clamped to between 5 and 120 seconds and defaults to 5 seconds.

types.name: DistributedTracingSpanProcessBoundary
types.description:
The position of a span with respect to the boundaries between processes in the trace.

---
**NR Internal** | [#help-dist-tracing](https://newrelic.slack.com/messages/C7GQYNEEB) | visibility(flag:`Distributed_Tracing/apiEarlyAccess`)

enumValues.name: ENTRY
enumValues.description: The first span in a process.

enumValues.name: EXIT
enumValues.description: A span that is the parent of an ENTRY span, or has an attribute name prefixed with either `db.` or `http.`, such as `db.statement` or `http.url`. If a span is both the first span in its process and has a `db.` or `http.`, its processBoundary value will be ENTRY.

enumValues.name: IN_PROCESS
enumValues.description: A span that is neither an ENTRY nor EXIT span. In-process spans are operations within each process, like internal method calls and functions.

types.name: WorkloadStatusSource
types.description:
Indicates where the status value derives from.

---
**NR Internal** | [#workloads-team](https://newrelic.slack.com/messages/CJJ3DA3SM) | visibility(customer)

enumValues.name: ROLLUP_RULE
enumValues.description: Refers to the result of an automatic rule defined for a workload.

enumValues.name: STATIC
enumValues.description: Refers to a static status defined for a workload.

enumValues.name: UNKNOWN
enumValues.description: Refers to an undetermined status source.

enumValues.name: WORKLOAD
enumValues.description: Refers to the override policy that is applied to a set of partial results within a workload. Any static status always overrides any other status values calculated automatically. Otherwise, the worst status of the partial results is rolled up.

types.name: EntitySearch
types.description:
A data structure that contains the detailed response of an entity search.

The direct search result is available through `results`. Information about the
query itself is available through `query`, `types`, and `count`.


---
**NR Internal** | visibility(customer)

fields.name: count
fields.description:
The number of entities returned by the entity search.

---
**NR Internal** | visibility(customer)

fields.name: counts
fields.description:
A count of the Entity Search results faceted by a chosen set of criteria.

Note: Unlike a NRQL facet, the facet results do not include entities where the facet value does not exist. Additionally, entities can be tagged with multiple tag values for one tag key. For these reasons, depending on the facet values chosen, the `counts` field will not always equal the `entitySearch.count` field.


---
**NR Internal** | visibility(customer)

args.name: facet
args.description:
A list of criteria to facet entities by.

This can be combined with the `facetTags` argument to facet by a combination of criteria and tags.

args.name: facetTags
args.description:
A list of tags to facet entities by. For example: `"environment"`, `"region"`.

This can be combined with the `facet` argument to facet by a combination of criteria and tags.

Note: If a tag does not exist on an entity, the entity will not be counted in the facet results. If an entity tag has multiple values, it will be counted in all facets that apply.

fields.name: query
fields.description:
The entity search query string.

---
**NR Internal** | visibility(customer)

fields.name: results
fields.description:
The paginated results of the entity search.

---
**NR Internal** | visibility(customer)

args.name: cursor
args.description: The cursor to fetch paginated entity search results.

fields.name: types
fields.description:
The entity types returned by the entity search.

---
**NR Internal** | visibility(customer)

types.name: AlertsNrqlConditionSignalInput
types.description:
Configuration that defines the signal that the NRQL condition will use to evaluate.

---
**NR Internal** | [#alerts-interfaces](https://newrelic.slack.com/messages/C0DSAFF8Q) | visibility(customer)

inputFields.name: aggregationWindow
inputFields.description:
Aggregation window controls the duration of the time window used to evaluate the NRQL query, in seconds.
The value must be at least 30 seconds, and no more than 15 minutes (900 seconds). Default is 60 seconds.

Baseline NRQL conditions only allow 60 seconds.

---
**NR Internal** | [#alerts-interfaces](https://newrelic.slack.com/messages/C0DSAFF8Q) | visibility(customer)

inputFields.name: evaluationOffset
inputFields.description:
Required, replaces `nrql.evaluationOffset`.

By default, we evaluate the NRQL query in one-minute time windows. The start time depends on the value you select in the NRQL condition's `evaluationOffset`. Evaluation offset cannot be greater than 20 minutes.

This value is the number of time windows we look back at the aggregated data.

Example: With an `evaluationOffset` of 3 and a 1 minute aggregation window, the NRQL time window applied to your query will be:

`SINCE 3 minutes ago UNTIL 2 minutes ago`

---
**NR Internal** | [#alerts-interfaces](https://newrelic.slack.com/messages/C0DSAFF8Q) | visibility(customer)

inputFields.name: fillOption
inputFields.description:
Which fill option to use. Defaults to STATIC.

---
**NR Internal** | [#alerts-interfaces](https://newrelic.slack.com/messages/C0DSAFF8Q) | visibility(customer)

inputFields.name: fillValue
inputFields.description:
If using the static fill option, this the value used for filling. Defaults to 0.

---
**NR Internal** | [#alerts-interfaces](https://newrelic.slack.com/messages/C0DSAFF8Q) | visibility(customer)

inputFields.name: evaluationOffset
inputFields.description:
Deprecated, replaced by `signal.evaluationOffset`.

By default, we evaluate the NRQL query in one-minute time windows. Start time depends on the value you select in the NRQL condition's `evaluationOffset`.Evaluation offset cannot be greater than 20 minutes.

This value is the number of time windows we look back at the aggregated.

Example: With an `evaluationOffset` of 3, the NRQL time window applied to your query will be:

`SINCE 3 minutes ago UNTIL 2 minutes ago`

types.name: NrdbResultContainer
types.description:
A data structure that contains the results of the NRDB query along
with other capabilities that enhance those results.

Direct query results are available through `results`, `totalResult` and
`otherResult`. The query you made is accessible through `nrql`, along with
`metadata` about the query itself. Enhanced capabilities include
`eventDefinitions`, `suggestedFacets` and more.


---
**NR Internal** | visibility(customer)

fields.name: currentResults
fields.description:
In a `COMPARE WITH` query, the `currentResults` contain the results for the current comparison time window.


---
**NR Internal** | visibility(customer)

fields.name: embeddedChartUrl
fields.description:
Generate a publicly sharable Embedded Chart URL for the NRQL query.

For more details, see [our docs](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/graphql-api/tutorials/query-nrql-through-new-relic-graphql-api#embeddable-charts).


---
**NR Internal** | [#help-dashboard-services](https://newrelic.slack.com/messages/CPXF9VA2Z) | visibility(customer)

args.name: chartType
args.description:
The type of chart visualization you want rendered.

We will default to the best fit for the provided NRQL query if omitted.

fields.name: eventDefinitions
fields.description:
Retrieve a list of event type definitions, providing descriptions
of the event types returned by this query, as well as details
of their attributes.


---
**NR Internal** | [#help-dashboard-services](https://newrelic.slack.com/messages/CPXF9VA2Z) | visibility(customer)

fields.name: metadata
fields.description:
Metadata about the query and result.

---
**NR Internal** | visibility(customer)

fields.name: nrql
fields.description:
The [NRQL](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/insights/nrql-new-relic-query-language/nrql-resources/nrql-syntax-components-functions) query that was executed to yield these results.

---
**NR Internal** | [#help-nrdb](https://newrelic.slack.com/messages/C6TAJ4XKN) | visibility(customer)

fields.name: otherResult
fields.description:
In a `FACET` query, the `otherResult` contains the aggregates representing the events _not_
contained in an individual `results` facet


---
**NR Internal** | visibility(customer)

fields.name: previousResults
fields.description:
In a `COMPARE WITH` query, the `previousResults` contain the results for the previous comparison time window.


---
**NR Internal** | visibility(customer)

fields.name: results
fields.description:
The query results. This is a flat list of objects who's structure matches the query submitted.

---
**NR Internal** | [#help-nrdb](https://newrelic.slack.com/messages/C6TAJ4XKN) | visibility(customer)

fields.name: staticChartUrl
fields.description:
Generate a publicly sharable static chart URL for the NRQL query.

---
**NR Internal** | [#help-dashboard-services](https://newrelic.slack.com/messages/CPXF9VA2Z) | visibility(customer)

args.name: chartType
args.description:
The type of static chart visualization you want rendered.

We will default to the best fit for the provided NRQL query if omitted.

args.name: format
args.description: The type of static chart format you want rendered.

args.name: height
args.description: The height of static chart format you want rendered.

args.name: width
args.description: The width of static chart format you want rendered.

fields.name: suggestedFacets
fields.description:
Retrieve a list of suggested NRQL facets for this NRDB query, to be used with
the `FACET` keyword in NRQL.

Results are based on historical query behaviors.

If the query already has a `FACET` clause, it will be ignored for the purposes
of suggesting facets.

For more details, see [our docs](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/graphql-api/tutorials/nerdgraph-graphiql-nrql-tutorial#suggest-facets).


---
**NR Internal** | [#help-ais](https://newrelic.slack.com/messages/C1X96SDA4) | visibility(customer)

fields.name: suggestedQueries
fields.description:
Suggested queries that could help explain an anomaly in your timeseries based on either statistical differences in the data or historical usage.

If no `anomalyTimeWindow` is supplied, we will attempt to detect a spike in the NRQL results. If no spike is found, the suggested query results will be empty.

Input NRQL must be a TIMESERIES query and must have exactly one result.


---
**NR Internal** | [#help-ais](https://newrelic.slack.com/messages/C1X96SDA4) | visibility(customer)

args.name: anomalyTimeWindow
args.description: The time window of a specific anomaly in milliseconds since Epoch time.

fields.name: totalResult
fields.description:
In a `FACET` query, the `totalResult` contains the aggregates representing _all_ the events,
whether or not they are contained in an individual `results` facet


---
**NR Internal** | visibility(customer)

**NR Internal** | [#alerts-interfaces](https://newrelic.slack.com/messages/C0DSAFF8Q) | visibility(customer)

fields.name: aggregationWindow
fields.description:
Aggregation window controls the duration of the time window used to evaluate the NRQL query, in seconds.
The value must be at least 30 seconds, and no more than 15 minutes (900 seconds). Default is 60 seconds.

Baseline NRQL conditions only allow 60 seconds.

---
**NR Internal** | [#alerts-interfaces](https://newrelic.slack.com/messages/C0DSAFF8Q) | visibility(customer)

fields.name: evaluationOffset
fields.description:
By default, we evaluate the NRQL query in one-minute time windows. The start time depends on the value you select in the NRQL condition's `evaluationOffset`. Evaluation offset cannot be greater than 20 minutes.

This value is the number of time windows we look back at the aggregated data.

Example: With an `evaluationOffset` of 3 and a 1 minute aggregation window, the NRQL time window applied to your query will be:

`SINCE 3 minutes ago UNTIL 2 minutes ago`

---
**NR Internal** | [#alerts-interfaces](https://newrelic.slack.com/messages/C0DSAFF8Q) | visibility(customer)

fields.name: fillOption
fields.description:
Which fill option to use. Defaults to STATIC.

fields.name: fillValue
fields.description:

types.name: AlertsNrqlConditionUpdateQueryInput
types.description:
Information for generating the condition NRQL query.
Output from this NRQL query will be compared to the condition terms to detect violations.

---
**NR Internal** | [#alerts-interfaces](https://newrelic.slack.com/messages/C0DSAFF8Q) | visibility(customer)

inputFields.name: evaluationOffset
inputFields.description:
Deprecated, replaced by `signal.evaluationOffset`.

By default, we evaluate the NRQL query in one-minute time windows. Start time depends on the value you select in the NRQL condition's `evaluationOffset`.Evaluation offset cannot be greater than 20 minutes.

This value is the number of time windows we look back at the aggregated data.

Example: With an `evaluationOffset` of 3, the NRQL time window applied to your query will be:

`SINCE 3 minutes ago UNTIL 2 minutes ago`

---
**NR Internal** | [#alerts-interfaces](https://newrelic.slack.com/messages/C0DSAFF8Q) | visibility(customer)

types.name: TaggingMutationErrorType
types.description:
The different types of errors the API can return.

---
**NR Internal** | [#help-entity-platform](https://newrelic.slack.com/archives/CH5MLECNN) | visibility(customer)

enumValues.name: CONCURRENT_TASK_EXCEPTION
enumValues.description: Too many concurrent tasks for the same GUID are being sent and we cannot process. Please serialize your requests for the given GUID.

enumValues.name: INVALID_DOMAIN_TYPE
enumValues.description: Domain Type invalid. The decoded domain type from the provided GUID is not valid. Please provide a correct GUID.

enumValues.name: INVALID_ENTITY_GUID
enumValues.description: We could not decode the provided GUID. Entity guid needs to be base64 encoded.

enumValues.name: INVALID_KEY
enumValues.description: The tag key is not valid. Char length has been reached, contains a disallowed character(eg :) or is empty

enumValues.name: INVALID_VALUE
enumValues.description: The tag value is not valid. Char length has been reached, contains a disallowed character(eg :) or is empty

enumValues.name: NOT_FOUND
enumValues.description: The given GUID or tag you're looking for does not exist.

enumValues.name: NOT_PERMITTED
enumValues.description: You've attempted to do something your Domain/EntityType is not permitted to do. Its also possible that an api key is required.

enumValues.name: TOO_MANY_TAG_KEYS
enumValues.description: The given entity has reached its tag key count limit. You will need to delete existing tags for the given GUID before continuing.

enumValues.name: TOO_MANY_TAG_VALUES
enumValues.description: The given entity has reached its tag value count limit. You will need to delete existing values for the given GUID before continuing.

enumValues.name: UPDATE_WILL_BE_DELAYED
enumValues.description: The changes will be reflected in the entity with some delay

types.name: AlertsMutingRuleConditionInput
types.description:
A condition which describes how to target a New Relic Alerts Violation.

---
**NR Internal** | [#alerts-interfaces](https://newrelic.slack.com/messages/C0DSAFF8Q) | visibility(customer)

inputFields.name: attribute
inputFields.description:
The attribute on a violation. Expects one of:

* **accountId** - The account id
* **conditionId** - The alert condition id
* **policyId** - The alert policy id
* **policyName** - The alert policy name
* **conditionName** - The alert condition name
* **conditionType** - The alert condition type, such as `metric`
* **conditionRunbookUrl** - The alert condition's runbook url
* **product** - The target product (e.g., `SYNTHETICS`)
* **targetId** - The ID of the alerts target
* **targetName** - The name of the alerts target
* **nrqlEventType** - The NRQL event type
* **tag** - Arbitrary tags associated with some entity (e.g., FACET from a NRQL query)
* **nrqlQuery** - The NRQL query string

---
**NR Internal** | [#alerts-interfaces](https://newrelic.slack.com/messages/C0DSAFF8Q) | visibility(customer)

inputFields.name: operator
inputFields.description:

**NR Internal** | [#alerts-interfaces](https://newrelic.slack.com/messages/C0DSAFF8Q) | visibility(customer)

inputFields.name: values
inputFields.description:
The value(s) to compare against the attribute's value.

fields.name: entitySearch
fields.description:
Search for entities using a custom query.

For more details on how to create a custom query
and what entity data you can request, visit our
[entity docs](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/graphql-api/tutorials/use-new-relic-graphql-api-query-entities).

Note: you must supply either a `query` OR a `queryBuilder` argument, not both.


---
**NR Internal** | [#help-entity-platform](https://newrelic.slack.com/messages/CH5MLECNN) | visibility(customer)

args.name: options
args.description: Additional options to apply to the entity search.

args.name: query
args.description:
Entity search query string.
The query string can search for an exact or fuzzy match on name, as well as searching several other attributes.

Note: you must supply either a `query` OR a `queryBuilder` argument, not both.

Operators available: `=`, `AND`, `IN`, `LIKE`
Entity queries use the same syntax of a WHERE clause in NRQL queries.

Examples:
- `"name = 'MyApp (Staging)'`
- `"name LIKE 'MyApp' AND type IN ('APPLICATION')"`
- `"reporting = 'false' AND type IN ('HOST')"`
- `"domain IN ('INFRA', 'APM')"`

args.name: queryBuilder
args.description:
The query builder object can be used to discover and create the entity search query argument.
To see the query string that is generated, ask for the query field in the result object.

Note: you must supply either a `query` OR a `queryBuilder` argument, not both.

args.name: sortBy
args.description: The criteria used to sort your entity search results.

fields.name: nerdStorage
fields.description:
NerdStorage is a document database that is accessible within the New Relic One interface.
This allows for persistence of Nerdpack data including users' configuration settings and preferences
(like favorites), or any other small data sets.

Conceptually, you can imagine NerdStorage as a nested key-value map.

For information on New Relic NerdStorage, visit [our docs](https://developer.newrelic.com/build-tools/new-relic-one-applications/nerdstorage).

To use the NerdStorage schema you must specify a Nerdpack ID using the NewRelic-Package-Id header in your request.

types.name: AlertsNrqlConditionQuery
types.description:
Information for generating the condition NRQL query.
Output from the evaluated NRQL query will be compared to the condition terms to detect violations.

---
**NR Internal** | [#alerts-interfaces](https://newrelic.slack.com/messages/C0DSAFF8Q) | visibility(customer)

fields.name: evaluationOffset
fields.description:
By default, we evaluate the NRQL query in one-minute time windows. The start time depends on the value you select in the NRQL condition's `evaluationOffset`. Evaluation offset cannot be greater than 20 minutes.

This value is the number of time windows we look back at the aggregated data.

Example: With an `evaluationOffset` of 3, the NRQL time window applied to your query will be:

`SINCE 3 minutes ago UNTIL 2 minutes ago`

fields.name: attribute
fields.description:
The attribute on a violation. Expects one of:

* **accountId** - The account id
* **conditionId** - The alert condition id
* **policyId** - The alert policy id
* **policyName** - The alert policy name
* **conditionName** - The alert condition name
* **conditionType** - The alert condition type, such as `metric`
* **conditionRunbookUrl** - The alert condition's runbook url
* **product** - The target product (e.g., `SYNTHETICS`)
* **targetId** - The ID of the alerts target
* **targetName** - The name of the alerts target
* **nrqlEventType** - The NRQL event type
* **tag** - Arbitrary tags associated with some entity (e.g., FACET from a NRQL query)
* **nrqlQuery** - The NRQL query string

fields.name: collection
fields.description:
Nerdpack documents are stored inside a collection.
A collection can be thought of as a key-value storage where each document is one of these key-value pairs.

To use the NerdStorage schema you must specify a Nerdpack ID using the NewRelic-Package-Id header in your request.


---
**NR Internal** | [#help-nr1-platform-services](https://newrelic.slack.com/messages/C9PU1820Z) | visibility(customer)

args.name: collection
args.description: The collection from which documents will be retrieved.

fields.name: document
fields.description:
A Nerdpack document is formed by an identifier (called documentId) and a set of data associated with it.

To use the NerdStorage schema you must specify a Nerdpack ID using the NewRelic-Package-Id header in your request.


---
**NR Internal** | [#help-nr1-platform-services](https://newrelic.slack.com/messages/C9PU1820Z) | visibility(customer)

args.name: collection
args.description: The collection that the document belongs to.

args.name: documentId
args.description: The documentId to be retrieved.

types.name: ID
types.description:
The `ID` scalar type represents a unique identifier, often used to
refetch an object or as key for a cache. The ID type appears in a JSON
response as a String; however, it is not intended to be human-readable.
When expected as an input type, any string (such as `"4"`) or integer
(such as `4`) input value will be accepted as an ID.

types.name: AlertsNrqlConditionPriority
types.description:
Value determining whether to open a critical or warning violation for a NrqlCondition.

---
**NR Internal** | [#alerts-interfaces](https://newrelic.slack.com/messages/C0DSAFF8Q) | visibility(customer)

enumValues.name: CRITICAL
enumValues.description: When a critical priority violation occurs, notifications will be sent. The number of incidents opened and notifications sent depends on the incident preference defined in the condition's policy.

enumValues.name: WARNING
enumValues.description: Does not generate notifications. Use a warning priority when you want to monitor when a system behavior is concerning or noteworthy, but not important enough to require a notification.

types.name: AlertsIncidentPreference
types.description:
Determines how incidents are created for critical violations of the conditions contained in the policy.

---
**NR Internal** | [#alerts-interfaces](https://newrelic.slack.com/messages/C0DSAFF8Q) | visibility(customer)

enumValues.name: PER_CONDITION
enumValues.description:
A condition will create a condition-level incident when it violates its critical threshold.
Other violating conditions will create their own incidents.

enumValues.name: PER_CONDITION_AND_TARGET
enumValues.description:
Each target of each condition will create an entity-level incident upon critical violation.
Other violating targets will create their own incidents (even on the same condition).

enumValues.name: PER_POLICY
enumValues.description:
A condition will create a policy-level incident when it violates its critical threshold.
Other violating conditions will be grouped into this incident.

fields.name: nerdStorage
fields.description:
NerdStorage is a document database that is accessible within the New Relic One interface.
This allows for persistence of Nerdpack data including users' configuration settings and preferences
(like favorites), or any other small data sets.

Conceptually, you can imagine NerdStorage as a nested key-value map.

For information on New Relic NerdStorage, visit [our docs](https://developer.newrelic.com/build-tools/new-relic-one-applications/nerdstorage).

To use the NerdStorage schema you must specify a Nerdpack ID using the NewRelic-Package-Id header in your request.


---
**NR Internal** | visibility(customer)

fields.name: nrql
fields.description:
Make a query to NRDB with a NRQL string.

See the [NRQL Docs](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/insights/nrql-new-relic-query-language/nrql-resources/nrql-syntax-components-functions) for more information about generating a query string.

Example NRQL query:
```
SELECT count(*) FROM Transaction TIMESERIES
```

For more details on how to use NRQL in the GraphQL API, visit [our docs](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/apis/graphql-api/tutorials/query-nrql-through-new-relic-graphql-api)


---
**NR Internal** | visibility(customer)

args.name: query
args.description: The [NRQL](https://docs.newrelic.com/docs/insights/nrql-new-relic-query-language/nrql-resources/nrql-syntax-components-functions) query string.

args.name: timeout
args.description: The timeout we will apply to the NRQL Query. The value will be clamped to between 5 and 120 seconds and defaults to 5 seconds.
